question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate, professional responses. Make sure the generated code is executable for demonstration. Create a mini-program that calculates the tensile resistance of anchor bolts according to the "Technical Code for Building Pile Foundations," configure a UI, and ensure it can run directly.

checklist.title: Is the core calculation function for anchor bolt tensile resistance implemented correctly?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements the calculation formulas based on the 'Technical Code for Building Pile Foundations'. Check if all required parameters are included (such as anchor diameter, embedded depth, concrete strength, etc.) and if the calculations follow the standard equations. Score 0 if calculations are missing, 5 if basic calculations are implemented but with errors, and 10 if all formulas are correctly implemented according to the technical code.

checklist.title: Are all necessary input parameters and their constraints handled properly?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the program accepts all required parameters for accurate tensile resistance calculation. Check if the code validates input ranges according to the technical standards (e.g., minimum/maximum values for bolt diameters, concrete strength grades). Deduct 3 points for each missing critical parameter, 2 points for inadequate validation, and 5 points if the units of measurement are inconsistent or unclear. Full score for comprehensive parameter handling with proper validation.

checklist.title: Does the program implement different calculation scenarios as per the technical code?
checklist.description: Check if the program handles different anchor bolt types, installation methods, and special conditions as specified in the technical code. Score 3 points for each properly implemented scenario (straight anchors, bent anchors, different failure modes). Deduct 5 points if the program only implements a single basic scenario without considering variations. Maximum 10 points for comprehensive coverage.

checklist.title: Is the user interface properly designed for engineering applications?
checklist.description: Assess if the UI is designed with engineering professionals in mind. Check for clear labeling of input fields with units, appropriate use of engineering terminology, logical grouping of related inputs, and presentation of results with proper significant figures. Deduct 3 points for confusing terminology, 3 points for poor input organization, and 4 points if results lack proper engineering context or units. Full score for a professional engineering-oriented interface.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle various input errors (non-numeric inputs, out-of-range values, etc.) and edge cases. Check for proper error handling with informative messages that guide users to correct inputs. Deduct 2 points for each unhandled error case, and 5 points if the program crashes on invalid inputs. Give 10 points if robust error handling is implemented throughout.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that enhance usability for engineers?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes features that improve workflow efficiency (e.g., 1. Quick result comparison between different parameters 2. Visualization of calculation results 3. Export functionality for reports). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementations of similar calculations 2. Functionality unrelated to anchor bolt calculations 3. Fancy effects that distract from the engineering application. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (separation of calculation logic from UI), code reusability, and maintainability. Check if the code follows clear naming conventions appropriate for engineering software. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is high; deduct 3 points if variable/function names don't reflect engineering concepts. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional engineering software standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the design follows professional engineering software principles: 1) Clean, distraction-free interface 2) Clear hierarchy of information 3) Consistent formatting of numerical values and units. Deduct 3 points for each cluttered section, 5 points for poor contrast affecting readability, and 5 points for inconsistent representation of technical information. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the calculation workflow intuitive and efficient?
checklist.description: Judge whether the application workflow matches how engineers would approach these calculations: 1) Logical progression from inputs to results 2) Ability to quickly modify parameters and recalculate 3) Clear distinction between input, calculation, and output phases. Deduct 4 points for workflows requiring unnecessary steps, 3 points for calculations that don't update promptly after input changes, and 5 points if the calculation process is unclear to users. The full score is 10 points.
